title: 108_hr1002
content: The Act titled "Training and Research in Urology Act of 2003" focuses on research, training, and dissemination of health information related to urologic diseases. The Public Health Service Act is amended to reorganize the Division Director positions for Urologic Diseases, Kidney Diseases, and Hematologic Diseases. The Act emphasizes research support programs. The Public Health Service Act is amended to reorganize Division Director positions for Urologic Diseases, Kidney Diseases, and Hematologic Diseases. Programs for research, training, evaluation, planning, and dissemination of knowledge related to various diseases are established. The Public Health Service Act is amended to reorganize Division Director positions for Urologic Diseases, Kidney Diseases, and Hematologic Diseases. Programs for research, training, evaluation, planning, and dissemination of knowledge related to various diseases are established. Additionally, $500,000 is authorized for each of fiscal years 2004 and 2005 for the development and review of a national urologic research plan every 3 years starting in 2009. The Public Health Service Act is amended to reorganize Division Director positions for Urologic Diseases, Kidney Diseases, and Hematologic Diseases. Programs for research, training, evaluation, planning, and dissemination of knowledge related to various diseases are established. Additionally, the Director of the Institute shall establish the National Urologic Diseases Data System for the collection, storage, analysis, retrieval, and dissemination of data derived from patient populations with urologic diseases. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish the National Urologic Diseases Information Clearinghouse to enhance knowledge of urologic diseases. The Urology Interagency Coordinating Committee is strengthened by reorganizing positions and committees. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish the National Urologic Diseases Information Clearinghouse and strengthen the Urology Interagency Coordinating Committee by reorganizing positions and committees. The Urology Interagency Coordinating Committee may support activities in urology research and receive appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2008. The Public Health Service Act is amended to expand O'Brien Urologic Disease Research Centers, ensuring a minimum of 15 centers focused on various aspects of urologic diseases. This includes research on pediatrics, interstitial cystitis, incontinence, stone disease, urinary tract infections, and benign prostatic diseases. Authorization of appropriations is also included in the amendment. The Public Health Service Act is amended to expand O'Brien Urologic Disease Research Centers, with a minimum of 15 centers focusing on urologic diseases. Authorization of appropriations totaling $22,500,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008 is included. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to subsection (c) of section 431, and a subcommittee on Urologic Diseases is established under section 432. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish a subcommittee on kidney, urologic, and hematologic diseases. Loan repayment incentives are introduced to encourage urologists and scientists to pursue research careers. Loan repayment program introduced to encourage urologists and scientists to pursue research careers in urology. The Secretary will enter contracts with health professionals or scientists for urology research, repaying up to $35,000 of educational loans annually. Professionals must have significant educational loans relative to income and work for the National Institutes of Health or academic urology departments. The program established under subsection (a) requires health professionals or scientists to work for the National Institutes of Health or academic urology departments for at least 3 years to fulfill the research requirement. The provisions of the National Health Service Corps Loan Repayment Program apply to this program. Authorization of appropriations for urology research is also included in the amendment. Authorization of appropriations for urology research includes funding of $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008, with additional funding as needed for intra- and interagency activities, training programs, joint research projects, and clinical trials.
